subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

I know this is an automated message, but I wanted to reach out anyway. Iâ€™ve
been a product manager for over 20 years and a self-described "geek" long
before that. While Iâ€™ve dabbled in PHP, HTML, and CSS for WordPress sites,
Iâ€™ve never been a coder who builds from scratchâ€”the barrier to entry for
creating production-ready software was always too high for someone with my
schedule and family commitments.

However, "vibe coding" with AI has changed everything. I started with
Lovable and have since moved on to using OpenCode (best) and Cursor
(Antigravity is too flaky). Iâ€™ve been able to build extremely useful tools
and websites for my small family business, and with the integration of
GitHub and Vercel, the deployment process essentially takes care of itself.

Iâ€™m interested in staying current with these self-work tools, but I'm also
fascinated by what this means for the profession of software development.
As a product leader, my job spans business & vision vision, through
ideation, and to prod. We are seeing the removal of the primary bottleneck:
the cost and time associated with manual software production and
maintenance. For example, I recently used Codex 5.2 to add a complex 3D
modeling feature to an internal app for my wifeâ€™s business. I simply spoke
the requirements, and it handled the documentation, UI integration, and
database updates instantly.

In my career, that kind of update would have taken weeks or months of PRDs,
release planning, and architectural compromises. I have also seen cycle
times of years. Now, I can move from an idea to a preview environment in
minutes. The speed of iterationâ€”which Agile and SAFe could never solveâ€”is
finally here because we are no longer limited by manual syntax entry by
devs.

I followed you after seeing a recommendation from Theo at T3, specifically
regarding your agents.md article. The idea that "best practices" are now
prompts (or just conversations) rather than rigid frameworks is a massive
shift. Even if the AI doesn't get it right the first time, the cost of
iterating five different versions is lower than the cost of a single
planning meeting.

Software development is having its "horse to engine" moment. And what this
means beyond just software development as well.
Best regards,

Graeme Port

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,



Yeah, your TypeScript content has been genuinely useful over the yearsâ€”those short videos on generics finally made things click.



Iâ€™ve been watching your AI Hero pivot with interest. Similar trajectory hereâ€”I recently created an â€œAI Context Engineerâ€ role for myself at Aflac after realising AI was changing how I work.



What interests me most:

Context engineeringâ€”the gap between AI that occasionally helps and AI that consistently delivers. Iâ€™ve been building systems that accumulate knowledge across development sessions.



Multi-agent coordinationâ€”orchestrating specialised agents for different development phases. The coordination problem is where it gets interesting.

Evaluationâ€”how do you actually measure if your AI setup is improving? Currently building harnesses to test different context configurations.



What I want to learn more about: how to drive adoption. Part of my role is educating engineers in my organisation and building confidence with AI tools. Youâ€™ve done this at scale with TypeScriptâ€”curious whatâ€™s worked for you in getting developers past the initial scepticism.



Barry



Sent from my iPhone

Hi Matt,

I want to learn how to effectively use AI to boost my productivity and get
more stuff done. I donâ€™t like it when AI does everything by itself but
rather use it like a co-coder to facilitate my own work. This might be due
to the complexity of processes and products iâ€˜m working on - AI just isnâ€˜t
there yet.
Please focus on web technologies and workflows that are already well
established. Bleeding edge tech is interesting but of no real use if itâ€˜s
going to be replaced in a year.

Cheers,
Tim

Hi Matt.


I bought Typescript Essentials Course to understand what is the problem it
solved and how does it fit in the industry.

In terms of AI is, how can I translate PRD's into a working code (not
efficient but effective) using is training, so I can also learn what new
features AI agent suggest, why and what problem does it solve?.

Yet again, the AI model must be update with recent training.

Thank you for the course and your patience.

Eulier

â€‹Hi Matt,

â€‹Great to hear from you. Iâ€™ve been following your work in the TypeScript
ecosystem for a while.

â€‹Coming from a structured world like TypeScript, AI feels like a massive
paradigm shift. Iâ€™m most interested in *integration and application layers*.
I want to move beyond just using ChatGPT in the browser and start building
AI features directly into my applications.

â€‹Specifically, I want to learn:

   - â€‹How to reliably integrate LLMs into TypeScript codebases (using tools
   like the Vercel AI SDK or LangChain).
   - â€‹How to constrain AI outputs so they are type-safe and predictable.
   - â€‹The best patterns for building RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
   systems.

â€‹Looking forward to seeing what youâ€™re working on!



Regards,
Mandar

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
BartÅ‚omiej Wojcieszek has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Organizer
team@aihero.dev
team@aihero.dev

Guests
(Guest list has been hidden at organizer's request)

subject: Past materials

triggerMessage.subject: Past materials
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt, big fan of your TS work. Been trying to get into AI and was happy
and bummed out to find your AI Hero site some weeks ago. Happy because you
are a great instructor but bummed because I missed the second cohort by a
few days (I'm assuming there was a first one which I therefore missed) and
now the event about Ralph sold out in just a few hours... Man I'm so sad...
I don't want to miss out on the opportunity to learn all you have to
teach... Please, tell me, are you planning to repeat the cohorts/events in
the future? Again, big fan of your work, thanks.

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt. I am very aware of who you are - I've paid for your courses (I
think the mailing list should give it away lol), and follow you on LinkedIn
and YouTube.

I am a front-end swe at Google. Formerly at Dialogflow and Firebase, now at
Google News. I currently contribute to the Gemini Web UI.

I want to learn how others are using AI and how I can improve or tweak my
ever evolving daily workflows. I am very skeptical of this Ralph concept
(not your course). I hope I can make it off the waitlist, enroll in a
future course, or pay for a recorded version. My skepticism of Ralph stems
from the excessive jargon and word salad in Geoffrey Huntley's post
<https://ghuntley.com/ralph/> and some YouTube interviews. I am absolutely
certain I will learn something from your course and it will be time and
money well spent, but the Ralph concept feels very snake oily. Isn't this a
very temporary problem? Is a standard solution
<https://venturebeat.com/orchestration/mits-new-recursive-framework-lets-llms-process-10-million-tokens-without>
to the context rot issue far off?

Can't Gemini and Claude Code with MCP do this out of the box? Did the blog
post need to be longer than the first two lines?

*If you've seen my socials lately, you might have seen me talking about
Ralph and wondering what Ralph is. Ralph is a technique. In its purest
form, Ralph is a Bash loop.*



*```while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude-code ; done```*

Anyway, I was hoping the course would prove me wrong and that I'd gain a
new trick or two. I am especially interested in seeing how agents are
orchestrated and your approach to writing PRDs. Also, I'd just love to talk
to other devs to learn/share how LLMs can improve our workflows. For me,
it's mostly on the communication side: writing documents, drafting emails,
preparing for performance reviews, and understanding new [to me] codebases.

Thanks for all you do. I've learned a lot!

Jeff

to the context rot issue far off?

Can't Gemini and Claude Code with MCP do this out of the box? Did the blog
post need to be longer than the first two lines?

*If you've seen my socials lately, you might have seen me talking about
Ralph and wondering what Ralph is. Ralph is a technique. In its purest
form, Ralph is a Bash loop.*



*```while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude-code ; done```*

Anyway, I was hoping the course would prove me wrong and that I'd gain a
new trick or two. I am especially interested in seeing how agents are
orchestrated and your approach to writing PRDs. Also, I'd just love to talk
to other devs to learn/share how LLMs can improve our workflows. For me,
it's mostly on the communication side: writing documents, drafting emails,
preparing for performance reviews, and understanding new [to me] codebases.

Thanks for all you do. I've learned a lot!

Jeff

Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â 

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

The Fresh Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Community Forum is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Inside Flyball

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Town Hall meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Claude Code running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

Unsubscribe ( https://track.customer.io/unsubscribe/dgSN7QkDAMWyRMSyRAGb5093BVbNPOU14sKobfk= ) ãƒ»

* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

subject: Re: [aih] Re: Plan for 2026

triggerMessage.subject: Re: [aih] Re: Plan for 2026
triggerMessage.body:
Okay got it!

First, great news about the workshop sales selling out ğŸ™Œ that is great
signal.

Given this, and of course your own motivation being a huge piece of the
success, here's what we're thinking for the big picture year long plan at a
very high level:

*Each quarter is punctuated by a cohort and we work backwards from that. *

Within each quarter, you'll have a combination of components:

   - *A smaller product launch. *Think something on par with the half day
   workshop or AI-SDK Crash Course)that provides both revenue AND
   assets/insights that carry forward and compound
   - *At least one new FREEBIE launch, aimed at the top of funnel. *This
   would tie into your Twitter/Youtube activity and be designed to get people
   from those platforms to the list
   - *At least one cohort. *I say at least one, because this could *also* turn
   into a rhythm where on month 1 of a quarter you re-run a past cohort, and
   month 3 you launch a new one. This exact rhythm could vary, but the goal
   would be to blend the leverage of cohorts that people missed the first time
   AND introducing new things that you're excited about.

In the case of Q1 (now), since it's almost the end of Jan already and this
cohort is effectively your small product launch in Feb, I don't think we
will be able to fit a re-run in but we can absolutely plan for it at the
top of Q2.

We'd map this out on a calendar to make sure it's clear and the overlapping
timelines make sense, but wanted to share this first for an initial gut
check.

How's that land for you?








-Alex

ğŸ¤  my community: indyhall.org
ğŸ“ˆ  my 10 year goal: 10k.city

conversationHistory.body:
Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for this
year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:

Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
finalized tomorrow.

First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks away.

Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set deadlines
for when we want to solidify the content.

That should let us plan backwards effectively from those dates, with the
knowledge that we may alter them if we want to change course (do a smaller
ship between two cohorts, or drop a cohort for 2 small ships, or repeat a
cohort and do a smaller ship in the downtime). No plan survives contact
with the anemone, after all.

Matt

Proposal would be:

Ralph Cohort: 30th March
Cohort 2: 29th June
Cohort 3: 14th September
Cohort 4: 7th December

On Mon, Jan 19, 2026 at 5:58â€¯PM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for this
> year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:
>
> Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
> finalized tomorrow.
>
> First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks away.
>
> Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set
> deadlines for when we want to solidify the content.
>
> That should let us plan backwards effectively from those dates, with the
> knowledge that we may alter them if we want to change course (do a smaller
> ship between two cohorts, or drop a cohort for 2 small ships, or repeat a
> cohort and do a smaller ship in the downtime). No plan survives contact
> with the anemone, after all.
>
> Matt
>

Amy and I talked about this yesterday and think it's a great set of dates
to scaffold backwards from! Also love an 8 week lead time to the next
cohort ğŸ˜

That said - are you open to guidance on this next cohort being Ralph vs a
second run of the assistant cohort?

Remember from our call that our recommendation for this year is to think
about launches/events as layered events, strategically staggering new
releases between relaunches with improvements and additions, as well as
smaller experimental releases (workshops, crash courses, etc)

A few reasons we both agree that this would be a more advantageous path:

- our recommended rhytm for the year is going to be a mix of new launches +
relaunches. This not only helps you increase the income for effort on each
course, it also helps demonstrate and reinforce your investment in each
ideas you teach to the audience.

- the half day workshop in early Feb about Ralph will let you learn a lot
about the response to that topic and how/what to expand for the larger
cohort version of on the same topic, BUT if anything changes we'll likely
end up having to change the plan and have less time to work on the March
cohort.

However if you run the Assistant cohort again in March, that lets you:

- increase the leverage of that material, in addition to any fixes to the
material itself, with a lot less effort than a new cohort now

- let us get a running start on the relaunch of that cohort while you're
running the half day workshop, without worry about the workshop changing
the course of that work in a significant way

- let YOU pace your effort and time between the half day workshop and the
next cohort better as well

- assuming the Ralph feedback and demand DOES match your expectations, a
best case scenario is you decide to fast track the 2nd cohort of 2026 and
it's possible because the first one isn't being produced from scratch and
you could actually do both in parallel.

Overall, this second version helps you retain a lot more flexibility and
optionality that fits the fast changing landscape, while also keeping a
pace and rhythm that holds people's attention.

Hopefully it's clear why it's pretty important that we get on the same page
about this now ğŸ˜„

I'm sure there are some tweaks we can make, and most importantly this
doesn't change anything about your current plans to do the smaller Ralph
workshop!

How's this land for you? Questions or concerns or strong disagreement we
should talk thru?

We wanna get working on the plan for the year and this is gonna be a
foundation, so we wanna get it right!

Happy to do a quick call to chat this thru too if it's helpful.

Thanks for the above. But I do disagree: I'm pretty convinced that Ralph
for Cohort 1 is the way forward.

As a bit of signal, we opened up a Ralph workshop sales page at $375 and it
sold out (40 seats) in 3 hours.

I think this bit of signal, plus my own passionate interest, is leading me

I'm interested in the topic, and feel a strong surge of consumer interest.
The half-day workshop work directly feeds into the cohort, so I don't feel
like it's too much of a push for me to get a whole cohort ready on this
topic before mid-March.

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Jason Wilbur has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt/AI Hero team,

Excited for the course! I have a few questions below so that I'm best prepared:

> What you need to bring Technical requirements:
>
> - GitHub account with a repo you can work on

Does this repo need to be public, or can it be private work-related?
Better if my repo is full-stack, front-end, or back-end?
Any other guidance on the repo (which programming language, webapp or mobile app, etc.) for the smoothest 4 hours? I have flexibility and am asking because I'll be creating the repo for the course.

> - Any one of these AI coding CLIs installed and working:
>
> - Claude Code (Opus 4.5)
> - OpenCode
> - Copilot CLI
> - Codex (GPT 5.2)

Do you always stick with a specific agent while Ralphing? With my legacy pre-Ralph HITL Cursor AI ways, I would find even the smartest agents (Opus 4.5 and GPT 5.2) can struggle or hit a dead-end while the other smart agent can sometimes quickly solve, so at times I flip agents. Perhaps you never encountered this, or perhaps those clear PRDs of yours make the problem far less or non-existant.

Thanks!
Jon

On Thursday, January 22nd, 2026 at 6:20 AM, Matt Pocock (AI Hero) <matt@aihero.dev> wrote:

> Hey ,
>
> The future of AI coding is a loop. Itâ€™s one of the simplest primitives available to developers, but weâ€™ve been criminally underusing it in the AI coding world.
>
> Instead, weâ€™re stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants. You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
>
> But hereâ€™s whatâ€™s actually happening right now in production: developers are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created. Without constant babysitting.
>
> Itâ€™s called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and itâ€™s not magic. Itâ€™s a simple, learnable pattern.
>
> Iâ€™m running [a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST](https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0ueoedk3mf6h5zw07gtlho9x0577a8hddpp4/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx) to teach you exactly how to build it. Weâ€™re capping at 40 developers because this is hands-on. Youâ€™ll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching me code.
>
> Hereâ€™s what youâ€™ll leave with:
>
> - Your own bash loop running
> - Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
> - Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
> - The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
>
> By 1 PM, youâ€™ll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.
>
> Sign-ups are open now. Limited spots, and weâ€™ve got a discount running through Feb 5th. Grab yours before they sell out.
>
> The full details are here, including what actually breaks, why this works now (and didnâ€™t before), and exactly what you need to bring.
>
> [Secure Your Seat](https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0ueoedk3mf6h5zw07gtlho9x0577a8hddpp4/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx)

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Milan Stojanovic has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Organizer
team@aihero.dev
team@aihero.dev

Guests
(Guest list has been hidden at organizer's request)

You are receiving this email because you are subscribed to calendar notifications. To stop receiving these emails, go to https://calendar.google.com/calendar/r/settings, select this calendar, and change "Other notifications".

Forwarding this invitation could allow any recipient to send a response to the organizer, be added to the guest list, invite others regardless of their own invitation status, or modify your RSVP.

The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

triggerMessage.body:
Paul Ferguson has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Hi, last July I bought the "Build DeepSearch in TypeScript
<https://www.aihero.dev/cohorts/build-deepsearch-in-typescript>" using my
corporate account. I got fired last week and I can't access anymore the
email I used (carlos.mourullo@commercetools.com). I would like to know if I
could somehow transfer the license to my personal email address.

I have the same issue with the https://www.totaltypescript.com/ license
but, since last week there was a discount and I didn't get any reply to a
previous email I sent, I would like to also take the opportunity to ask if
I can also regain access to that account.

Regards,
Carlos

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

Thanks for reaching out. I'm like you also was a part of the TS world for a
long time. Now time has changed and I feel like I'm getting behind with all
AI innovations.
There are a few areas that interest me about AI:

   - Product development - how can AI models/agents/workflows enhance my
   product, how can I make users life easier.
   - Software development lifecycle - how can AI help me to write better
   code and deliver better product features.

I think, in more general terms, I'm interested in understanding how to
design and build AI flows, be it agents or workflows. I'm also interested
in learning how to assess different models to be able to choose one that
suits the use-case best.

I hope it helps.

Cheers,
Anton

subject: AI is so confusing, where do i start?

triggerMessage.subject: Re: AI is so confusing, where do i start?
triggerMessage.body:
The knowledge base isn't returning results, but here's what I'd suggest: Start with the fundamentals section in AI Hero. It covers core concepts like how AI models work, prompt engineering basics, and common use cases. Work through one module at a time rather than trying to absorb everything at once.
What specific part of AI are you most interested in - the theory side, practical applications, or something else?

subject: Proposal Investment

triggerMessage.subject: Proposal Investment
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Dear, 
 My name is Brayan Parker, and I'm taking the liberty of contacting you about your project, for which I've identified potential interest on the part of our network of investors.  I would therefore like to know if you are currently looking for financing. 
 I represent an asset management company specializing in project financing.  
 We have a strong and diversified investor portfolio, including business angels, family offices and venture capital (VC) funds.  We can intervene in the form of credit or equity, with a minimum entry ticket of â‚¬300,000. 
 If you are in the process of raising funds, please do not hesitate to contact me so that we can discuss your project in greater detail. I'd also be delighted to provide you with more information about our company and the investor profiles we support. 
 Best Regards, Brayan Parker Our website:  https://diagram-investments.com

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,

Thanks for reaching out. I've been following your TypeScript work for a
while now.

Regarding AI, there is obviously a lot of reasonable hype right now, but
social media is saturated with rage-bait, exaggerations, and people
misrepresenting what's actually possible just for engagement.

I'm mostly interested in cutting through that noise to find clear,
grounded, and true perspectives on what is really happening in the AI
coding space.

Best,
Javier
